areas.name: Capacity
areas.description: This area describes the ability of society to recognise threats and prevent incidents.

subareas.name: Cyber hygiene
subareas.description: Implementation of measures for cyber hygiene.

subareas.name: Cybersecurity awareness
subareas.description: Knowledge and understanding of cybersecurity and efforts to increase cybersecuirty awareness.

subareas.name: Cybersecurity skills and education
subareas.description: Availability of measures to increase specialised cybersecurity skills and knowledge.

areas.name: Market/Industry
areas.description: This area describes the ability of the private sector to prevent, detect, and analyse cyber threats and incidents.

subareas.name: Cybersecurity investments and innovation
subareas.description: Extent to which enterprises invest into their current and future security.

subareas.name: Cybersecurity governance within organisations
subareas.description: Extent to which enterprises implement policy and measures to prevent cyber incidents.

subareas.name: Large enterprises: Impact of cybersecurity incidents
subareas.description:
Extent to which large enterprises have suffered
from cybersecurity incidents.

subareas.name: SMEs: Impact of cybersecurity incidents
subareas.description: Extent to which SMEs have suffered from cybersecurity incidents.

areas.name: Operations
areas.description: This area describes the ability of a MS to carry out operations to ensure resilience.

subareas.name: Threat and vulnerability management
subareas.description: Efforts for threat and vulnerability management.

subareas.name: Operational cooperation
subareas.description: Definition of a framework for cooperation at the national level.

subareas.name: National-level response preparedness
subareas.description: Extent to which a country is prepared to deal with cyber-related issues.

subareas.name: Resilience of key operators
subareas.description:
Resilience of key operators in
terms of incidents and their duration.

areas.name: Policy
areas.description: This area describes the state of policy development and implementation.

subareas.name: Policies for knowledge
subareas.description: Definition of a policy framework for the development of cybersecurity knowledge.

subareas.name: Coverage and enforcement of legal and regulatory framework
subareas.description: Existence and coverage of national cybersecurity legislations.

subareas.name: International cooperation
subareas.description: Alignment with international practices and policies.

subareas.name: National-level risk management
subareas.description: Coverage of risk-management at national level.

euWideIndicators.algorithm:
Sector Criticality = Sum of assigned scores on specific criticality dimensions/ Sum of maximum scores that could be assigned per criticality dimension * 100

Scores are assigned by experts during workshops held with  established groups of national authorities and/or EU-level ISACs

Source: ENISA NIS 360 Project

Sector Criticality = Sum of assigned scores on specific criticality dimensions/ Sum of maximum scores that could be assigned per criticality dimension * 100

Scores are assigned by experts during workshops held with  established groups of national authorities and/or EU-level ISACs

Source: ENISA NIS 360 Project

euWideIndicators.indicator: Share of surveyed suppliers of cryptographic products with EU-based design and development
euWideIndicators.algorithm:
Value = Share of surveyed suppliers of cryptographic products with EU-based design and development

Source: ENISA Cloud Cybersecurity Market Analysis

euWideIndicators.indicator: Average knowledge gap related to cryptographic product and services between the demand side and the supply side of such product/services
euWideIndicators.algorithm:
Value = Average knowledge gap related to cryptographic product and services between the demand side and the supply side of such product/services as assessed by surveyed suppliers (areas considered: verification/testing, implementation, design, integration, management and operation, generic knowledge of trust chain

Source: ENISA Cloud Cybersecurity Market Analysis

domains_of_excellence.subareaDescription: Extent to which SMEs have suffered from cybersecurity incidents.
domains_of_excellence.indicator: SMEs: Security Incidents - Disclosure of confidential data
domains_of_excellence.algorithm:
Share of SMEs that did not experience ICT security related incidents leading to: disclosure of confidential data (e.g. due to intrusion, pharming, phishing attack, actions by own employees intentionally or unintentionally)

Value = 100 - Value of variable E_SEC2ICNF ("Enterprises experienced ICT security related incidents leading to: disclosure of confidential data (e.g. due to intrusion, pharming, phishing attack, actions by own employees intentionally or unintentionally)")

Source:  Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
domains_of_excellence.w100means: All SMEs did not experience incidents leading to disclosure of confidential data

domains_of_excellence.subareaDescription: Definition of a framework for cooperation at the national level.
domains_of_excellence.algorithm:
Share of CSIRTs that participate in international activities

Value = #of CSIRT Teams member of FIRST in country+#of CSIRT Teams listed-accredited-certified TI/# of CSIRTs in a country that are either CNW members, FIRST members or TI Listed/Certfied/Accredited- average share of CSIRTs that are either FIRST members or L/C/A or both

Source: ENISA - CSIRTs by country
domains_of_excellence.w100means: In all EU Member States, CSIRTs are FIRST members and TI Listed/Accredited/Certified

domains_of_excellence.subareaDescription: Extent to which SMEs have suffered from cybersecurity incidents.
domains_of_excellence.indicator: SMEs: Security Incidents - Destruction or corruption of data
domains_of_excellence.algorithm:
Share of SMEs that did not experience ICT security related incidents leading to: destruction or corruption of data (e.g. due to infection of malicious software or unauthorised intrusion, hardware or software failures)

Value = 100 - Value of variable E_SEC2IDCD ("Enterprises experienced at least once problems due to ICT security incident: destruction or corruption of data")

Source:  Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
domains_of_excellence.w100means: All SMEs did not experience incidents leading to destruction or corruption of data

domains_of_excellence.subareaName: Large enterprises: Impact of cybersecurity incidents
domains_of_excellence.subareaDescription:
Extent to which large enterprises have suffered
from cybersecurity incidents.
domains_of_excellence.indicator: Large enterprises: Security Incidents - Disclosure of confidential data
domains_of_excellence.algorithm:
Share of Large enterprises that did not experience ICT security related incidents leading to: disclosure of confidential data (e.g. due to intrusion, pharming, phishing attack, actions by own employees intentionally or unintentionally)

Value = 100 - Value of variable E_SEC2ICNF ("Enterprises experienced ICT security related incidents leading to: disclosure of confidential data (e.g. due to intrusion, pharming, phishing attack, actions by own employees intentionally or unintentionally)")

Source:  Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
domains_of_excellence.w100means: All large enterprises did not experience incidents leading to disclosure of confidential data

domains_of_excellence.subareaDescription: Implementation of measures for cyber hygiene.
domains_of_excellence.algorithm:
Share of Internet users who changed the way they use the internet due to security concerns

Value = Value for QC5 (Total - None/ You are not concerned about online security (SPONTANEOUS) - Don't know)

Source: Eurobarometer - Special Eurobarometer 499 : Europeans' attitudes towards cyber security (cybercrime)
domains_of_excellence.w100means: All internet users have changed the way they use the internet due to security concerns

domains_of_improvement.subareaDescription: Extent to which enterprises invest into their current and future security.
domains_of_improvement.indicator: Enterprises using AI technologies for ICT security
domains_of_improvement.algorithm:
Share of enterprises that use AI technologies for ICT security

Value = Value of variable E_AI_PITS

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
domains_of_improvement.w100means: 75% (digital decade target) of enterprises  use AI technologies for ICT security

domains_of_improvement.subareaDescription: Extent to which enterprises invest into their current and future security.
domains_of_improvement.algorithm:
Average share of information security budget spending by surveyed essential/important entities as part of their overall IT budget/spending

Source: ENISA NIS Investments Report
domains_of_improvement.w100means: The whole IT budget of surveyed essential/important entities is devoted to  information security

domains_of_improvement.subareaDescription: Extent to which a country is prepared to deal with cyber-related issues.
domains_of_improvement.algorithm:
Share of trusted introducer certified CSIRTs

Value=  # of Certified CSIRTs/CSIRTs Under Re-Certification  in a country/# of CSIRTs in a country that are either CNW members, FIRST members or TI Listed/Certfied/Accredited

Source: ENISA - CSIRTs by country
domains_of_improvement.w100means: In all EU Member States, CSIRTs  are TI certified

domains_of_improvement.subareaDescription: Availability of measures to increase specialised cybersecurity skills and knowledge.
domains_of_improvement.algorithm:
Share of EU R&D funding awarded per country = EU Contribution for Horizon Europe calls related to cybersecurity in year n/EU contribution for HORIZON EUROPE under cluster 3- Civil Security for Society calls per country

Source: Horizon Dashboard
domains_of_improvement.w100means: In all EU MS, Cybersecurity topics have recieved all the country's EU R&D funding for  the Horizon Europe security cluster

domains_of_improvement.subareaDescription: Extent to which enterprises implement policy and measures to prevent cyber incidents.
domains_of_improvement.algorithm:
Share of  enterprises performing a cybersecurity risk assessment

Value = Value of variable E_SECMRASS

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
domains_of_improvement.w100means: All enterprises perform a cybersecurity risk assessment

areas.name: Capacity
areas.description: This area describes the ability of society to recognise threats and prevent incidents.

subareas.name: Cyber hygiene
subareas.description: Implementation of measures for cyber hygiene.

indicators.algorithm:
Share of large enterprises using at least one of the following ICT security measures: 
* Strong password authentication (E_SECMSPSW)
* Combination of at least two authentication mechanisms (e.g. user-defined password, one-time password (OTP), code generated via a security token or received via a smartphone, biometric methods) (E_SECMDUO)
* Encryption techniques for data, documents or e-mails (E_SECMDENC)
* Data backup to a separate location (including backup to the cloud) (E_SECMOSBU)
* Network access control (management of access by devices and users to the enterprise's network) (E_SECMNAC)
* VPN (Virtual Private Network extends a private network across a public network to enable secure exchange of data over public network) (E_SECMVPN)
* Maintainance of log files for analysis after security incidents (E_SECMLOG)
* Performance of ICT security tests (E_SECMTST)

Value = Weighted value of 8 variables (E_SECMSPSW; E_SECMDUO; E_SECMDENC; E_SECMOSBU; E_SECMNAC; E_SECMVPN; E_SECMLOG; E_SECMTST)
Weight = 1/8 per variable

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All large enterprises implement relevant ICT security measures

indicators.indicator: Citizens: privacy and protection of personal data
indicators.algorithm:
Share of individuals that managed access to personal data on the internet by performing at least one of the following actions: 

* read privacy policy statements before providing personal data
* restricted or refused access to the geographical location
* limited access to profile or content on social networking sites or shared online storage
* refused allowing the use of personal data for advertising purposes
* checked that the website where personal data provided was secure

Value =  Value of variable I_MAPS_5 (% of individuals that manage access to personal data on the internet (3 months) by performing at least one of the following actions: I_MAPS_RPS, I_MAPS_RRGL, I_MAPS_LAP, I_MAPS_RAAD, I_MAPS_CWSC)
indicators.w100means: All individuals take at least one appropriate privacy-preserving measures when using internet

indicators.algorithm:
Share of Internet users who changed the way they use the internet due to security concerns

Value = Value for QC5 (Total - None/ You are not concerned about online security (SPONTANEOUS) - Don't know)

Source: Eurobarometer - Special Eurobarometer 499 : Europeans' attitudes towards cyber security (cybercrime)
indicators.w100means: All internet users have changed the way they use the internet due to security concerns

indicators.algorithm:
Share of SMEs using at least one of the following ICT security measures: 
* 	Strong password authentication (E_SECMSPSW)
* 	Combination of at least two authentication mechanisms (e.g. user-defined password, one-time password (OTP), code generated via a security token or received via a smartphone, biometric methods) (E_SECMDUO)
* 	Encryption techniques for data, documents or e-mails (E_SECMDENC)
* 	Data backup to a separate location (including backup to the cloud) (E_SECMOSBU)
* 	Network access control (management of access by devices and users to the enterprise's network) (E_SECMNAC)
* 	VPN (Virtual Private Network extends a private network across a public network to enable secure exchange of data over public network) (E_SECMVPN)
* 	Maintainance of log files for analysis after security incidents (E_SECMLOG)
* 	Performance of ICT security tests (E_SECMTST)


Value = Weighted value of 8 variables: E_SECMSPSW; E_SECMDUO; E_SECMDENC; E_SECMOSBU; E_SECMNAC; E_SECMVPN; E_SECMLOG; E_SECMTST
Weight = 1/8 per variable

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All SMEs implement relevant ICT security measures

subareas.name: Cybersecurity awareness
subareas.description: Knowledge and understanding of cybersecurity and efforts to increase cybersecuirty awareness.

indicators.algorithm:
Share of large enterprises that make persons employed aware of their obligations in ICT security related issues  

Value = Value of variable E_SECAWANY

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All large enterprises implement relevant ICT security measures

indicators.algorithm:
Share of internet users who  feel very-well/well informed about the risks of cybercrime AND/OR are aware of the existence of a website, email address, online form, or contact number in their country where they can report a cybercrime or any other illegal online behaviour (e.g. cyberattack, online harassment or bullying)

Value = Weighted value of 2 variables:
* 	% of internet users who feel very-well/well informed about the risks of cybercrime (question QC7 - Total 'Well informed')
* 	% of internet users who are aware of the existence of a website, email address, online form, or contact number in their country where they can report a cybercrime or any other illegal online behaviour (e.g. cyberattack, online harassment or bullying)? (question QC13 - Total 'Yes, you are aware of their existence')

Weight: 1/2 for each variable

Source: Eurobarometer - Special Eurobarometer 499 : Europeans' attitudes towards cyber security (cybercrime)
indicators.w100means: All internet users  feel very-well/well informed about the risks of cybercrime AND/OR are aware of the existence of a means to report illegal online behaviour

indicators.algorithm:
Share of SMEs:
* 	that provided their employees with training or awareness raising about the risks of cybercrime in the last 12 months and/or
* 	whose management feels that they are very well/well informed about the risks of cybercrime  and/or
* 	whose employees feel that they are very well/well informed about the risks of cybercrime

Value = Weighted values of multiple Eurobarometer variables:
* 	% of SMEs that provided their employees with training or awareness raising about the risks of cybercrime in the last 12 months (Q5 from fl_496_volume_A - 'Yes')
* 	% of SMEs whose management feels that they are very well/well informed about the risks of cybercrime (Q3 from fl_496_volume_A - Total 'Well informed')
* 	% of SMEs whose employees feel that they are very well/well informed about the risks of cybercrime(Q4 from fl_496_volume_A - Total 'Well informed')

Source: Eurobarometer - FL496 : SMEs and Cybercrime
Weight = 1/3 per variable
indicators.w100means: The management and employees of all SMEs feel that  they are very well/well informed about the risks of cybercrime

indicators.algorithm:
Share of SMEs that make persons employed aware of their obligations in ICT security related issues  

Value = Value of variable E_SECAWANY 

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All SMEs make their employee aware of their obligations related to ICT security

subareas.name: Cybersecurity skills and education
subareas.description: Availability of measures to increase specialised cybersecurity skills and knowledge.

indicators.algorithm:
Score (%) = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score 

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 7 "Strenghten training and educational programmes"
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States have implemented measures that show a high level of maturity in trainings

indicators.indicator: Tools and training to fight cybercrime
indicators.algorithm:
Score (%) = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score 

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 12 "Address cybercrime"
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States have implemented tools, procedures and trainings against cybercrime that show a high level of maturity

indicators.indicator: Cybersecurity exercises at national and international level
indicators.algorithm:
Score (%) = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 6 "Organise cybersecurity exercises"
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States have an  exercise program, also including participation at the international level, with a high level of maturirty

indicators.algorithm:
Share of EU R&D funding awarded per country = EU Contribution for Horizon Europe calls related to cybersecurity in year n/EU contribution for HORIZON EUROPE under cluster 3- Civil Security for Society calls per country

Source: Horizon Dashboard
indicators.w100means: In all EU MS, Cybersecurity topics have recieved all the country's EU R&D funding for  the Horizon Europe security cluster

indicators.algorithm:
Cybersecurity graduates in higher education

Value = Count of cybersecurity graduates in higher education curricula / Population in a country %

Source: ENISA Project - Cyberhead
indicators.w100means: The EU average reflects how EU compares to the country with the highest number of cybersecurity graduates per population in the EU.

areas.name: Market/Industry
areas.description: This area describes the ability of the private sector to prevent, detect, and analyse cyber threats and incidents.

subareas.name: Cybersecurity governance within organisations
subareas.description: Extent to which enterprises implement policy and measures to prevent cyber incidents.

indicators.algorithm:
Share of  enterprises performing a cybersecurity risk assessment

Value = Value of variable E_SECMRASS

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All enterprises perform a cybersecurity risk assessment

indicators.algorithm:
Share of  enterprises that have document(s) on measures, practices or procedures on ICT security

Value = Value of variable E_SECPOL2

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All  enterprises  have documents on measures, practices or procedures on ICT security

indicators.indicator: Organisations certified with relevant ISO standards
indicators.algorithm:
Share of organisations certified with at least one of the following standards: ISO 22301:2019 (Business continuity management systems);  ISO 27001:2013 (Information security management systems); ISO 28000:2007/ISO 28000:2022 (Security management systems) 

Value  = average %of organisations with any of the three ISO certificates = ( (metric 1 + metric 2 + metric 3)/3 ) %

metric 1 = Number of sites per country certified for ISO 22301:2019 / number of enterprises per country
metric 2 = Number of sites per country certified for ISO 27001:2013 / number of enterprises per country
metric 3 = Number of sites per country certified for ISO 28000:2007 / number of enterprises per country 

Source: ISO
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the the highest % of organisations certified with at least one relevant ISO standards.

indicators.indicator: Supply chain management by essential/ important entities
indicators.algorithm:
Average share of surveyed essential/important entities with third -party risk management policies

Source: ENISA NIS Investments Report
indicators.w100means:
All surveyed essential/important entities have third -party risk management policies

Source: ENISA NIS Investments Report

subareas.name: Cybersecurity investments and innovation
subareas.description: Extent to which enterprises invest into their current and future security.

indicators.algorithm:
Average share of information security budget spending by surveyed essential/important entities as part of their overall IT budget/spending

Source: ENISA NIS Investments Report
indicators.w100means: The whole IT budget of surveyed essential/important entities is devoted to  information security

indicators.indicator: Enterprises buying security software applications as a cloud computing service
indicators.algorithm:
Share of enterprises that buy security software applications (as a CC service)

Value = Value of variable E_CC_PSEC

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: 75% (digital decade target) of enterprises buy security software applications (as a CC service)

indicators.indicator: Enterprises using AI technologies for ICT security
indicators.algorithm:
Share of enterprises that use AI technologies for ICT security

Value = Value of variable E_AI_PITS

Source: Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: 75% (digital decade target) of enterprises  use AI technologies for ICT security

indicators.algorithm:
Share of EU R&D funding awarded to private SME for cybersecurity = EU Contribution to private SMEs for Horizon Europe calls related to cybersecurity in year n/EU contribution to private SMEs for HORIZON EUROPE under cluster 3- Civil Security for Society calls per country

Source: Horizon Dashboard
indicators.w100means: In all EU MS, SMEs  have recieved all the country's EU R&D funding for cybersecurity topics within  the Horizon Europe security cluster

subareas.name: Large enterprises: Impact of cybersecurity incidents
subareas.description:
Extent to which large enterprises have suffered
from cybersecurity incidents.

indicators.indicator: Large enterprises: Security Incidents - Destruction or corruption of data
indicators.algorithm:
Share of Large enterprises that did not experience ICT security related incidents leading to: destruction or corruption of data (e.g. due to infection of malicious software or unauthorised intrusion, hardware or software failures)

Value = 100 - Value of variable E_SEC2IDCD ("Enterprises experienced at least once problems due to ICT security incident: destruction or corruption of data")

Source:  Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All large enterprises did not experience incidents leading to destruction or corruption of data

indicators.indicator: Large enterprises: Security Incidents - Disclosure of confidential data
indicators.algorithm:
Share of Large enterprises that did not experience ICT security related incidents leading to: disclosure of confidential data (e.g. due to intrusion, pharming, phishing attack, actions by own employees intentionally or unintentionally)

Value = 100 - Value of variable E_SEC2ICNF ("Enterprises experienced ICT security related incidents leading to: disclosure of confidential data (e.g. due to intrusion, pharming, phishing attack, actions by own employees intentionally or unintentionally)")

Source:  Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All large enterprises did not experience incidents leading to disclosure of confidential data

indicators.indicator: Large enterprises: Security Incidents - Unavailability of ICT Services
indicators.algorithm:
Share of Large enterprises that did not experience ICT security related incidents leading to: unavailability of ICT services (e.g. Denial of Service attacks, ransomware attacks, hardware or software failures)

Value = 100 - Value of variable E_SECI2USV <U+201C>Enterprises (SMEs) experienced at least once problems due to ICT security incident: unavailability of ICT services<U+201D>

Source:  Eurostat - European Union survey on ICT usage in enterprises
indicators.w100means: All large enterprises did not experience incidents leading to unavailability of ICT services

indicators.w100means: All SMEs did not experience incidents leading to disclosure of confidential data

areas.name: Operations
areas.description: This area describes the ability of a MS to carry out operations to ensure resilience.

subareas.name: National-level response preparedness
subareas.description: Extent to which a country is prepared to deal with cyber-related issues.

indicators.indicator: Dedicated cybercrime establishment within law enforcement and prosecution offices
indicators.algorithm:
Value  = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 12 "Address cybercrime"
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, cybecrime establishments within law enforcement and prosecution offices have a high level of maturity

indicators.algorithm:
Value  = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score 

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 13 "Establish incident reporting mechanisms"
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, incident reporting processes and tools have a high level of maturity

indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 11 "Protect critical information infrastructure"
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, tools and processes to monitor and communicate threats, including to important/essential entities, have a high level of maturity

indicators.algorithm:
Share of trusted introducer certified CSIRTs

Value=  # of Certified CSIRTs/CSIRTs Under Re-Certification  in a country/# of CSIRTs in a country that are either CNW members, FIRST members or TI Listed/Certfied/Accredited

Source: ENISA - CSIRTs by country
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, CSIRTs  are TI certified

subareas.name: Operational cooperation
subareas.description: Definition of a framework for cooperation at the national level.

indicators.algorithm: Value  = SUM ( Score for Qx) / Maximum total score
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States have implemented all relevant measures to ensure national-level cooperation

indicators.indicator: Establishment of a national reporting scheme for major cyber incidents
indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score 

*Q1 based on ES-IMC, R-GI-OE2-01 Incident taxonomy
*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 13 "Establish incident reporting mechanisms"
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, the national reporting scheme for significant incidents has a high level of maturity

indicators.indicator: Establishment of operational cooperation mechanisms against cybercrime
indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 12 "Address cybercrime"
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, operational cooperation mechanisms against cybercrime have a high level of maturity

indicators.algorithm:
Share of CSIRTs that participate in international activities

Value = #of CSIRT Teams member of FIRST in country+#of CSIRT Teams listed-accredited-certified TI/# of CSIRTs in a country that are either CNW members, FIRST members or TI Listed/Certfied/Accredited- average share of CSIRTs that are either FIRST members or L/C/A or both

Source: ENISA - CSIRTs by country
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, CSIRTs are FIRST members and TI Listed/Accredited/Certified

subareas.name: Resilience of key operators
subareas.description:
Resilience of key operators in
terms of incidents and their duration.

indicators.indicator: Participation by essential and important entities in a national or EU-level ISAC
indicators.algorithm: Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score
indicators.w100means: All essential/important entities in the EU are members of at least one ISAC, and each EU Member State  monitors such participation

indicators.algorithm:
e-communication resilience based on serious incident cases

Value = RANK (# of serious incident cases reported by citizen; high to low) / #EU MS

# of serious incident cases reported per citizen =  # of serious incident cases reported by country for year X / Population size

Source: ENISA Project - CIRAS
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the smallest number of serious incidents affecting e-communications per citizen.

indicators.algorithm:
e-communication resilience based on serious outage times

Value = RANK (SUM(serious incident reported outage times) /citizens by country); high to low) / #EU MS

Source: ENISA Project - CIRAS
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the shortest  duration of serious incidents affecting e-communications.

indicators.algorithm:
e-trust services resilience  based on serious incident cases

Value = RANK (# serious of incident cases reported per QC for eSignatures issued; high to low) / #EU MS

# of serious incident cases reported per QC for eSignatures issued =  # of serious incident cases reported by country for year X / number of QC for eSignatures issued

Source: ENISA Project - CIRAS
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the smallest number of serious incidents affecting e-trust services per QC for eSignatures issued.

indicators.algorithm:
e-communication resilience based on serious outage times

Value = RANK (SUM(outage times) /citizens by country); high to low) / #EU MS

Source: ENISA Project - CIRAS
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the shortest duration of serious incidents affecting e-trust services.

indicators.algorithm:
Resilience of essential and important entities based on serious incident cases

Value = RANK (# of incident cases reported per citizen: high to low) / #EU MS

# of serious incident cases reported per citizen = # of serious incident cases reported by country for year X / Population size

Source: ENISA Project - CIRAS
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the smallest number of serious incidents affecting important/essential entities

subareas.name: Threat and vulnerability management
subareas.description: Efforts for threat and vulnerability management.

indicators.algorithm:
RANK (average of the following variables normalised by IPs; rank high to low)/#EU MS:

* Vulnerability - Number of IPs that are exposed to at least one vulnerability
* SSL Expired - Number of IPs with expired SSL certificate
* SSL Old Protocol - Number of IPs with old protocols
* SSL self-signed - Number of IPs with self-signed SSL
* OS Linux - Number of IPs with old OS Linux
* OS Windows - Number of IPs with old OS Windows
* Port - Number of IPs with Ports considered that should not be publicly available on Internet (port 23,161,68,69,81,110,137,389,445,3389,5353)
* Banner - Number of IPs with "authentication disabled" banner 

Source: Shodan
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the smallest exposure to a relevant set of vulnerabilities.

indicators.algorithm:
RANK (Average normalised number of IPs exposed to the Shodan top-10 vulnerabilities; high to low)/#EU MS:
The list of CVEs:
cve-2015-0204
cve-2015-4000
cve-2022-32548
cve-2020-0796
cve-2014-0160
cve-2015-1635
ms15-034
cve-2019-0708
cve-2021-31206
cve-2021-43798
cve-2021-40438
cve-2021-41773
cve-2021-42013
cve-2021-34473

Source: Shodan
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the smallest exposure to major CVEs.

indicators.indicator: Share of compromised IPs, services and servers
indicators.algorithm:
RANK (Average normalised by number of IPs in a country; rank high to low)/#EU MS of:

- Title - Number of websites with title containing "hacked by" or "0wn3d by"
- Banner - Number of IPs containing "hacked by" text in published banner
- Tag - Number of Compromised IPs, command and control seervers (C2) as marked by Shodan
- Product - Number of IPs with known security offensive tools like Cobalt Strike Beacon, Posh C2, Deimos C2, Empire C2, Brute Ratel C4
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the smallest exposure to a relevant set of compromised IPs, services and servers.

indicators.algorithm:
RANK (Average normalised by number of IPs in a country; rank low to high)/#EU MS of:

- SSL - Number of IPs using only modern TLS protocols without potential vulnerabilities, self-signed or expired certificates
- IPv6 - Number of IPs version6 without old SSL/TLS protocols, potential vulnerabilities, self-signed or expired certificates
- Banner - Number of websites with banners publishing "Content-Security Policy" without old SSL/TLS protocols, potential vulnerabilities, self-signed or expired certificates
indicators.w100means: The average reflects how the EU compares to the EU country with the highest usage of secure internet standards in the EU.

areas.name: Policy
areas.description: This area describes the state of policy development and implementation.

subareas.name: Coverage and enforcement of legal and regulatory framework
subareas.description: Existence and coverage of national cybersecurity legislations.

indicators.indicator: Coverage of essential sectors by national  legislation
indicators.algorithm: Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total of sectors
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, legislation covers all NIS2 sectors of high criticality, as well the NIS2 "other critical sectors"

indicators.algorithm: Value =   SUM ( Score Qx )  / Maximum total score
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, vulnerabilty disclosure policies cover all NIS2 sectors of high criticality, as well the NIS2 "other critical sectors"

indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM(state of eligible Directive)/TOTAL(number of eligible Directives)
    
State of eligible (cybersecurity related parts of) Directive/Regulation[s] =
- 100%  if the Directive is fully transposed (notification sent to the EC) and entered into force
- 70%  when legislation has been transposed (notification sent to the EC), but entry into effect is in the future.
- 40%  when national legislation partially covers Directive requirements, but full transposition is pending.
- 0%  otherwise
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States have implemented/transposed relevant EU regulations/directives on cybersecurity

indicators.indicator: Coverage and implementation of objectives in national cybersecurity strategy
indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM(Individual score per objective*) / number of pre-defined NCSS objectives 

* Individual score = SUM (Score for Qx**) / Maximum total score
** Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels for general common questions among the objectives
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, the cybersecurity strategy fully covers relevant objectives and has mechanisms for updates

subareas.name: International cooperation
subareas.description: Alignment with international practices and policies.

indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 17 "Engage in international cooperation (not only with EU MS)"
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States have implemented all relevant measures to implement and improve established cooperation mechanisms

indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score 

*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 17 "Engage in international cooperation (not only with EU MS)"
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States,  international cooperation on information sharing and the capacity to lead discussions have a high level of maturity

indicators.indicator: Alignment with the Council of Europe Convention on Cybercrime
indicators.algorithm:
Alignment with the Convention on Cybercrime (ETS No. 185); the first protocol on xebophobia and racism (ETS No. 189) and the second additional protocol on enhanced co-operation and disclosure of electronic evidence (CETS No. 224)

Value = Weight 1 (40%) * Alignment CETS 185 +  Weight 2 (40%) *  Alignment CETS 189 +  Weight 3 (20%)  * Alignment CETS 224

Alignment with ETS 185 /CETS 189/CETS 224:
If a country has signed AND ratified AND the convention has  entered into force date - 100%
else if a country has signed AND ratified - 80%
else if a country has signed - 15%
else 0  

Source: Council of Europe
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States the following documents have been ratified and entered into force: Convention on Cybercrime (ETS No. 185); the first protocol on xebophobia and racism (ETS No. 189) and the second additional protocol on enhanced co-operation and disclosure of electronic evidence (CETS No. 224)

subareas.name: National-level risk management
subareas.description: Coverage of risk-management at national level.

indicators.indicator: Baseline cyber security risk management measures for essential/important entities
indicators.algorithm: Value = SUM ( Score for Qx*) / Maximum total score
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States mandate a relevant set of risk management measures for essential/important entities and collects compliance data from all entities

indicators.indicator: Definition and compliance of cybersecurity baseline(s) for essential and important entities
indicators.algorithm:
Value  = SUM ( Score for Qx*) / Maximum total score 

*Q1 based on ES-IMC, A-PC-OE3-02 - Cyber resilience requirements
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, the process to define cybersecurity baseslines for essential/important entities and to check their compliance has a  high level of maturirty

indicators.indicator: Identification of essential and important entities
indicators.algorithm: Value = SUM ( Score for Qx) / Maximum total score
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, the processes to deal with essential/important entities (e.g update of the list, identification of SMEs) have a high level of maturity

indicators.indicator: Implementation of supervisory measures for essential and important entities
indicators.algorithm: Value = SUM ( Score for Qx) / Maximum total score
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, all operators in scope of NIS2 are subjected to supervisory measures by national competent authorities

subareas.name: Policies for knowledge
subareas.description: Definition of a policy framework for the development of cybersecurity knowledge.

indicators.algorithm:
Value  = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score 
*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 7 "Strenghten training and educational programmes"
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States implemented all relevant measures to promote, include and enhance cybersecurity in higher levels of education

indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score

*Q1 based on ES-IMC, R-GI-OE2-01 Incident taxonomy
*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 13 "Establish incident reporting mechanisms"
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States have integrated cybersecurity curricula for primary and seconday education and updates them regularly

indicators.indicator: Cybersecurity in R&D priorities and initiatives
indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score
*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 8 "Foster R&D"
indicators.w100means: All EU Member States have implemented relevant measures to support and promote cybersecurity R&D activities

indicators.indicator: National and international cooperation for cybersecurity R&D
indicators.algorithm:
Value = SUM ( Score for Qx* ) / Maximum total score 
*Scoring based on adapted NCAF maturity levels, objective 8 "Foster R&D"
indicators.w100means: In all EU Member States, cooperation with national and international actors on cybersecurity R&D has a high-level of maturity
